awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of High-Power 100 kHz Laser for Recording Real-Time Movies of Ultrafast Molecular Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to predict and control the outcome of chemical reactions is essential for many areas of modern physics, chemistry and biology. This ability requires detailed knowledge of how individual atoms in molecules move to break, form, or rearrange chemical bonds between them during the reaction. This research project aims at obtaining high-resolution movies of such atomic motion. Since the atoms involved in chemical reactions move extremely fast, typically on a time scale of few tens of femtoseconds (one femtosecond is one millionth of a billionth of a second), ultrashort, femtosecond laser pulses are the only experimental tools capable of recording such movies in real time. However, because of the quantum nature of atoms and molecules, the outcome of any molecular reaction is not deterministic: even if one measurement precisely captures the positions of all atoms at a given time, the same measurement will have different outcomes if repeated several times, even under exactly identical conditions. The acquisition of a high-power laser system delivering a hundred thousand pulses (each shorter than 10 femtoseconds) per second will enable repeating such measurements millions of times, which is needed for the creation of a quantum-mechanical molecular movie. Each frame of a movie then reflects the probability of every possible configuration of atoms at different stages of the reaction, instead of a fixed picture of a molecule. Such movies will advance our understanding of fundamental chemical processes and provide input for applications in areas of national priority, ranging from efficient energy conversion and storage to synthesis of novel materials, drug design and molecular electronics.  This project is jointly funded by the Major Research Instrumentation program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).
 

Within this project, a broad range of photochemical processes, including photodissociation and isomerization, charge transfer reactions and formation of van der Waals clusters, will be studied. For each of these processes, the main scientific goal is to image the time-dependent molecular geometry and simultaneously characterize the evolving electronic structure of the molecule. This will be achieved by employing several complementary time-resolved techniques, including photoelectron spectroscopy and ion momentum imaging, inner-shell and laser-induced photoelectron diffraction, as well as ion beam techniques and Fourier-transform spectroscopy for characterization of the neutral fragments. For all these techniques, the key technical aspect facilitating simultaneous characterization of electronic and nuclear degrees of freedom will be the coincident detection of several reaction products, enabled by the high repetition rate of the acquired laser. At the same time, its high average power of several hundred watts will enable the efficient conversion of the emitted near-infrared radiation to a broad range of different wavelengths (from long-wavelength infrared to extreme ultraviolet and soft x-rays) needed for initiating and probing the reactions to be studied.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Within this project, a new high-power, 100 kHz femtosecond laser system was acquired, installed and commissioned at the J. R. Macdonald Laboratory (JRML) at Kansas State University. It will be used for a variety of studies in ultrafast photochemistry and atomic, molecular and optical physics, with the main focus on recording “movies” of light-induced chemical reactions. Creating such “molecular movies” relies on coincident measurements of several reaction products, is realized by highly sophisticated charged-particle spectrometers often dubbed “reaction microscopes” and is limited to one laser-molecule interaction per laser shot. The new laser, which surpasses the lasers currently available at the JRML by a factor of 10 in repetition rate and average power, in combination with the “reaction microscopes” available at the JRML, enables new classes of experiments that otherwise will be feasible only at highly oversubscribed large-scale user facilities (like the Linac Coherent Light Source (LCLS) at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory). Several beamlines driven by the acquired laser system deliver femtosecond laser pulses in infrared, visible, ultraviolet and extreme ultraviolet spectral range, providing experimental tools for real-time mapping of femtosecond- and picosecond-scale chemical reactions. Particular modes of such experiments include, among others, Coulomb explosion imaging relying on three-dimensional multi-coincidence measurements of created ionic fragments, which provides direct information on the evolving molecular geometry; channel-selective photoelectron spectroscopy, which exploits coincident electron-ion detection and is sensitive to the electronic structure of the molecule; and laser-induced electron diffraction, which utilizes the ionized laser-driven electrons to image their parent molecule.

The results of such experiments will have a profound impact on our understanding of chemical reaction mechanisms, of ubiquitous concepts like “transition states”, structural intermediates, isomerization reactions, dynamics at conical intersections, and of the control of chemical reaction dynamics in general. The ability to record “molecular movies” of photochemical reactions enables benchmarking quantum chemistry calculations and therefore not only result in a better understanding of the underlying reaction mechanism, but ultimately also help to develop and optimize schemes for controlling the dynamics and outcome of such reactions. Imaging and controlling chemical reactions at the electronic level also has significant technological implications, and the tools and techniques developed and refined within the proposed project will thus have an impact that reaches beyond the femtochemistry and ultrafast physics communities.

The capabilities developed within this project significantly enhanced Kansas State University research infrastructure. In combination with a suit of charge-particle imaging spectrometers (including “reaction microscopes”) available at JRML, the acquired laser system will form a unique facility for multi-coincidence imaging experiments in ultrafast photochemistry, which can be used by internal and external users. Several research groups in the US besides JRML plan to actively use this unique capability. Moreover, challenges in data acquisition, processing and storage for such high repetition rate experiments that are addressed within this project have a profound impact of local JRML data handling infrastructure, and the experience gain here will facilitate the development of data acquisition and processing tools for the upcoming high repetition rate operation of the “reaction microscope” end station at the LCLS.

Technical capabilities developed within this project and associated training already contributed to the education of four Kansas State University graduate students. Resulting research capabilities will enhance training opportunities for large number of Kansas State students from Physics and Chemistry Departments, as well as from other collaborating institutions, including those  representing EPSCoR states. Since most of the graduate students trained in ultrafast laser technology and its applications will take positions in the high-tech industry upon graduation, it will make an impact on US competitiveness in this field and the US economy in the long run. Furthermore, many undergraduate students will be exposed to the cutting-edge ultrafast science research through the ongoing KSU REU program, and via collaborations with several undergraduate schools. Finally, the visual power and intuitiveness of “molecular movies” resulting this project will significantly facilitate outreach activities, allowing JRML researchers to efficiently promote quantum science, and make it more accessible and attractive to general public.
